title.narrative: Food assistance to the protracted IDPs affected by COVID-19 in Nangarhar

description.narrative:
Food insecurity in Afghanistan is on the rise due to continued conflict, high food prices, unemployment, and the new COVID-19 crisis, recent IPC analysis classified 4.3 million people in IPC-4 (emergency) and 9 million in IPC-3 (crises) of food insecurity.
In Nangarhar, the recent IPC analysis shows that a total of 210,326 people in urban areas are in Phase 3 (raised) and Phase 4 (emergency). and. Moreover, the last WoA assessment finding is indicating that 59% of the IDPs have poor FCS in Nangarhar, which shows the population is in emergency and need urgent food assistance.
Following the imposition of COVID-19 lockdowns resulting in a reduction in economic activities especially for the informal daily labor market and affected the capacity to recover their livelihood. The situation contributed to a steep increase in poverty leading to an alarming food insecurity situation.
Based on our assessment conducted in May 2020 in the urban areas in Nangarhar (city of Jalalabad district), clearly showed the emergency food insecurity situation and need for humanitarian assistance. The majority of the interviewed people reported that due to lockdown they lost income and do not have sufficient food. The shortage of food leads to an insufficient nutritional intake for all, and in particular for women and children. Other negative coping mechanisms push people to take loans, to sell their assets in the market for a low price, increasing their vulnerable situation, it is also possible that families marry off their daughters sooner and younger so that they have one mouth less to feed.
Through the proposed project ZOA and long-term strategic partner SHPOUL will provide unconditional cash assistance to a total of 16,700 individuals in order to help them meet their immediate food needs for 1 month. Each household will receive a one-time transfer of (6,500 AFN / 90 USD). Alongside the cash distribution, community mobilizers will visit all beneficiaries to conduct awareness training on COVID-19, and how to potentially mitigate Sexual Gender-Based Violence (SGBV), and Domestic Violence (DV) in the families, including a focus on child rights. Information leaflets will be distributed to ensure ongoing access to information. There will be special care for persons/families with special needs which will be listed separately and the team will distribute the bank cheque in their own locations. The project team also will ask this group of beneficiaries to be helped when collecting their cash from the bank. In the meantime, the team will ask the elders to assist such people when collecting their cash.
CHS and AWAAZ complaint mechanisms will be applied to be accountable to the beneficiaries and implement all activities in an accountable transparent way.
